awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Relational Pragmatics and Institution Work in Transitioning Industry
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will address how industries involving agricultural products evolve within the context of differing levels of regulation.  There are many studies of existing industries, but few regarding how industries for new products evolve.  In addition, these new industries are often subject to varying regulations across the contexts in which they are located, including conflict between federal and state regulations governing production, marketing and sales.  This conflict creates uncertainty for entrepreneurs and for the general public. This project will analyze how different political, cultural, and economic processes are shaping the ways that new industries are structured, and analyze the effects of these forces and uncertainties on entrepreneurs. More specifically, this study will address two questions.  First, when new industries evolve, who develops the capacity to change institutions? Second, how does the resulting structure from these institutional changes affect the experiences, frameworks, and practices of entrepreneurs more broadly? The project moves beyond questions about which social contexts are more and less likely to be associated with changes in institutions such as laws and customs of business because it also explores who is developing the capacity to influence these processes in real time. This research will provide insights into evolving industries that may be useful to state and national policymakers tasked with developing regulations to control industry operations. It will also provide insights to support entrepreneurship, thus contributing to higher levels of business creation and employment. 

This project will use a mixed-methods research design that includes analysis of three different states, each of which takes a different approach to regulating new agricultural products.  The project will include 70 semi-structured in-depth interviews with participants across the states, which will be analyzed using MAXQDA 2018 Analytics Pro software in order to identify patterns in the data that will be used in developing theoretical propositions.  These propositions will be tested with a subsequent cross-sectional survey of selected entrepreneurs across many states with a target response rate of 408 participants. These two approaches are combined to determine which institutions will persist over time and which ones will fail to persist.  Findings from this project will inform organizational theories of institutions focusing on the supply-side, sociology of culture theories of practice, and theories of social control in an effort to develop an integrated framework to explain how micro-level industry activities can produce macro-level social change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Alexander Kinney has completed his research for his dissertation "The Green Rush: Field Transformation, Institutional Change, and Social Control in the United States Cannabis Industry" supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. During the funding period, he spent three years interviewing and surveying stakeholders in the commercial cannabis market to identify how licensed cannabis businesses navigate being simultaneously legal and illegal under different regulatory contexts. As a sociologist, Kinney was interested in more broadly understanding how participants in "gray markets" influence the policies guiding them. 

During his research, Kinney was able to interview regulators, CEOs, managers, and front-line workers in cannabis retail and cultivation companies. Additionally, he interviewed medical professionals, lobbyists, and activists. These interviews were conducted with representatives from three state markets: California, Arizona, and Texas. At the time of study, each state hosted an exemplar case of each of the main types of operating commercial cannabis programs (e.g., adult-use, medical, and limited-use) to legally provision cannabis products to consumers. In addition to offering an in-depth glimpse into the day-to-day experiences of participants in the commercial cannabis market, these interviews also served as exploratory data to inform the creation of a questionnaire that was distributed at the national-level within every state that had an operational adult-use or medical cannabis program. The responses were collected to evaluate whether the types of experiences that interviewees described were commonplace throughout the United States. The data he collected sketches a picture of the how the commercial cannabis market operates in relation to ever changing laws and public opinion. 

The findings from this research had implications for scholarly theories of social change and practical understandings of how such a market could exist in U.S. society. Kinney developed a novel theory for how conflicting regulations can empower market participants to take a greater hand in shaping the policies governing them and proposed an explanation for how state cannabis laws continue to evolve to mirror the preferences of cannabis businesses. He also proposes new categories of surveillance in markets that can deepen scholarly understandings of why market participants engage in specific activities when faced with certain forms of governmental oversight. Additionally, through the analysis of the collected data he helped to contextualize the real-world impact of the banking challenges that cannabis businesses face, the lack of coherent regulatory support from government agencies, and the various forms of stigma that cannabis businesses manage in the course of their work. These findings are forthcoming and currently being evaluated for publication at peer-reviewed academic journals.


Kinney’s research on the commercial cannabis market forms the basis of his dissertation. Completed in 2022, the dissertation contributes to Sociology because it explains how gray markets survive when faced with many of the liabilities of fully illicit markets and few of the privileges of fully licit markets.

 


Last Modified: 06/07/2022
Modified by: Alexander Kinney
